summary: In the 1970s, a gangster goes undercover as a slave to assassinate the owner of a notorious gold mine.

reviews.review_title: Over-hyped movie with very ordinary plot line
reviews.content: Saw the 8+ rating of the movie and decided to give it a go. During the whole movie I tried to stop watching it multiple time, but kept on going hoping something good will happen and was utterly disappointed at the end. The movie has very old and cliche plot line. Typically, there is a protagonist who literally eve-teases a girl who at the end is wooed by his "persistence" (no wonder a lot of street goons are inspired by such characters making our country an unsafe place for women). The action is typical comical south-indian movie style where one punch from the "hero" sends villain in alternate dimension. The dialogues are crowd pleasing one line punchliners which might appeal to certain audience. Only good thing about the movie was decent acting by the lead actor.

There are so many slow motion secenes that if they were at normal speed movie would have ended in 70 min😪. I don't know when Indian movies will pass beyond mindset of 1 hero beating 1000 mens without having a single scratch. Very disappointed after suggested by 10 friends. Wasted my time.

I don't know why people overrate this movie. The plot it too confusing & less interesting. Screenplay is sometimes so slow & sometimes so fast.
movie is dull & boring.. & it's okay to skip it if you watch movies for entertainment & not for confusion.

The whole movie is illogical,,,from starting of movie to the last everyone praising the hero,,, nobody firing any bullet on him and he is killing all villians 😂😂😂😂 total time waste movie,,, worst script.

The movie had only punchlines and slo-mo action.
Whole movie is narrated by a character, it was never shown from the character's POV. There was action for every 10 mins.
Movie heavily relied on background score and dialogs, no acting. There were no normal movements.

reviews.review_title: Basically a stylized exercise in hero worship! [+44%]
reviews.content: K. G. F Chapter 1 might be an astonishing wonder for one section of film-goers who haven't yet been exposed to world cinema. But, honestly, it is little beyond an overstretched exercise in hailing the protagonist as invincible. The problem with films that have invincible heroes is that none of the challenges that the screenplay poses turns out to be engaging enough. This, in turn, makes K. G. F Chapter 1 a less than exciting experience.Prashant Neel has packaged the film with all necessary massy ingredients: there are slow-motion intro sequences, exquisitely staged yet pointless fights, and excessive hype created around the protagonist's indomitable aura. There are a bunch of scenes that try to reinstate the fact that Rocky (Yash) is unbeatable. It's clear from the very first scene that he's in. Yet, the director chooses to drive the point home over and over again. The dialogues too are some of the campiest I've heard in recent times. It's like no one in the film speaks normally. Everyone speaks as if they've been preparing their cheese-filled quotes/monologues for years, just waiting to spit them out at first given instance.Character-building is one area that the film lacks terribly in. We have more than a dozen (main) characters being introduced but none of them (and I repeat, none of them) are well-fleshed out. Even Rocky's childhood is just a collection of massy moments: he is pushed to the limit; his mom utters philosophical nonsense, and the next thing you see, he's beating people up in a jiffy. When Rocky grows older, he beats even more people up. Basically, the film uses the tired formula of one-man-against-many to build hype around the character of Rocky. This is something good old Shankar tried more than a decade ago and emerged a winner at. Prashant Neel attempts the same; he's supported greatly by his cinematographer Bhuvan Gowda (who assigns splendid colours to frames, often giving it a neo-noir touch), composer Ravi Basrur (the songs are bathroom-breaks but the background score was pretty epic), and the fine-looking production values (the set designs are elaborate).Where Neel lacks in the screenplay, he tries to compensate with cinematic gimmicks. The heroine, unfortunately, is a mere prop. She shows up in a couple of scenes (and a song) that do nothing but stretch the film's first half. In a film such as this, it would be criminal to even consider a well-written role for the heroine. In fact, the protagonist's mom (who appears in flashbacks) and a struggling pregnant mother at the gold mine receive better treatment than the heroine. Well, here's hoping she has something more to do in the sequel.The villains? I like how Prashant Neel tried to bring to the forefront not one, but a whole array of them. However, none of them manages to leave an impression. At the end of the day, they're just brawny halfwits who are not worthy of even tying the hero's shoelaces. K. G. F Chapter 1 certainly has a better second half (once the film shifts to the gold mine), though that it isn't saying much. I wish the director spent less time trying to write scenes glorifying Rocky and instead, focused on telling a more compelling story with well-rounded characters.I agree that a gangster movie needs its share of crowd-pleasing moments and even then, K. G. F Chapter 1 isn't a lot beyond an overly indulgent star vehicle. I'm not exactly sure if it's the packaging that impressed audiences or the frequent massy reminders; it definitely isn't the screenplay. Yash sleepwalks through the role of Rocky - one which thankfully doesn't require the greatest acting capabilities. This may be a benchmark for the Kannada film industry, but it's high time they realize they're still way behind when it comes to quality content and story-telling, because well, a brilliant technical crew can only do so much to elevate a mediocre screenplay. I hope to see more films along the lines of 'Lucia', 'Lifeu Ishtene', RangiTaranga', 'Kirik Party', and 'Thithi' instead of 'K. G. F'.

reviews.review_title: I'm honestly writing My Reviews about my feeling towards this movie
reviews.content:
Yeah ! I rated 1 stars, You know why? This movie makes no sense, and I'm completely shocked about how much hyped the movie is. Firstly, The main character Rocky is shown as a superhero ,yeah right an over the top action film protagonist , who fights with hundred people , and they just fly away. Yeah, it makes sense in South Indian Films where law of physics are not counted.
But we are in 2019 now and still watching this cringe? You are going to say, Superhero movies in hollywood does the same and we don't talk about that. duh, these are completely different genre. secondly, dialogues in the movie is okay for movies that released in 90's times. " Gangster to jo gang leke aata hain, wo hai monster" I Can't take anymore of this cringe. In fact, they wasted the whole film duration in developing the characters, Not a single shot where, Rocky is not shown. Maybe one or two? And the plot? Well, A boy from slum , his mother dies, this kind of story is common now.You want a gangster movie? Watch once upon a time in mumbai, see how it entertains you without having masala elements. Watch Gangster 2006 .

There are characters who want Rocky to win in the end and have made him easier to do do, That certainly gives an idea of how the past and uture story unveils in KGF Chapter 2. Enjoyed the movie with all heart :). Good luck and love to team KGF!

reviews.review_title: Snoozefest and Cringefest of Hero Worship
reviews.content:
Lot of problems with this movie:1. Pacing is abrupt.. some exposition scenes move too fast.. some scenes move so slow that you just want to fast forward them.2. Typical story: The backdrop of Kolar Gold Fields sounds interesting. Unfortunately, its only a backdrop and this film just becomes an ordinary gangster film. Hero infiltrates gang, woos heroine, kills villain. Have we seen this before?3. Too much cringe inducing Hero Worship: Yeah we get it, "Rocking Superstar" looks great and can make girls and some guys go gaga.. but having a slo-mo scene everytime he is on screen with voiceover explaining how he is the single best person on the face of this earth? Just pure cringe. Add to that the real world hero worship by the fans just shows you how politicians and film stars float on the sevenrh heaven in India.4. Headache inducing action: Rapid cuts and editing just make you dizzy.5. The heroine was there just for fun.. so were the item songs.6. What was the point the movie was trying to make? The mother makes her son promise that he will die a rich and powerful man. Ok understood. But richness and power can also be done in a legitimate way. Not by becoming a gangster and kiling people left right. An interesting story would have been if he got educated, became a minister or govt officer and then fought againt KGF mafia to win over the mines in a legitimate way. Maybe throwing in some fights for the required masala. Like Nayak.
TLDR: Just avoid and save 2.5 hours of your life.
This is a must watch movie . Yash has proved his potential

So, that's it? This is what people were getting excited for. This is what my friend kept recommending me for years. Literally, this was my reaction after watching KGF.Long story short, i wouldn't go in details and waste time, just like this film did. It's a typical south indian masala movie with no logic, heroism (portraying the hero as god), and slo mo action shots. Though one thing i liked was it's action sequences. It was well choreographed and don't mess with physics and logic unlike other south indian movies. The VFX was excellent, especially the gold mine scenes were visual and emotional treat. The atmosphere they build was very realistic and cinematography was good. But other than that, everything falls flat. It turns out to be a masala film that masses would cheer. If you have no experience in international cinema, you may enjoy it. But, looks like i can't digest it.

This is a very Hero centric film. Whole movie is about Slow motion shots, high on drama & low on impact lines. Every other moment their's an cinematic shot.
Seems as if story is forcefully made complicated to a point that is stops making sense. People who think this movie is "Fantastic" haven't seen any good films to differentiate between good & bad. DON'T WATCH IT & if you do you'll understand what I'm saying after half an hour & if you start liking it then it's a bigger problem.

Seriously, what was this? How can an ordinary man be so powerful? He can kill hundreds of people alone! So illogical! I don't know why people loved it, but I couldn't stand it at all. I was just counting how much minutes left.

You really can't take such a movie seriously. So many characters, coming and going. Nothing linear in the movie, goes from point A to Z in seconds. I had a few laughs though. Only positive some shots were well lit and directed.But , I guess I am the dumb one here, because people have liked this. So the joke's on me. It's one of the biggest movies in India, and it's made money. Watch it and decide on your own, not for everyone.
Don't waste your time, money, efforts on this piece of trash. Pushpa is way better then this one in each and every aspect. It is the publicity which has driven excess craze for this movie.

reviews.review_title: Chapter 1 sets the stage for a Macro level showdown in Chapter 2.
reviews.content: What's Passion? To work or put efforts on something repeatedly until you get it absolutely right, which one loves and holds close to the heart without getting distracted even for a second. In one of the interviews Prashant Neel, the Director had said that he has watched KGF more than 150 times while editing. He wanted to make his KGF, a near perfect craft. While shooting, Bhuvan Gowda, the cinematographer used to carry around 40kgs of the camera and its accessories on top while canning the sequences in windy and dusty region. The gigantic sets used to come down crashing after heavy wind and rains yet the Art Director, Shivakumar used to go back in erecting the same sets as they stood earlier. Yash, used to give multiple retakes with no sign of fatigue or feeling bored in that dust bowl.KGF will be made in two chapters. The chapter 1 is out and at the outset, it traces with pre-historical chronology world of events letting the audience know the importance of owning Gold and the battles for it. The chapter 1 deals with micro level of unorganized crime, Mafia and underworld. The Chapter 1 depicts about the greed and the race for one-up man-ship within many characters in getting the control of Goldmine, KGF. To enter into the Macro level of an orbit of world crime syndicate, one has to clear his way at the micro level. The dirt has to be cleaned to make way to the top. The chapter 1 ends at the doorstep of Chapter 2, which is meant to open for the Triangular battle between International mafia (for Gold), The interruption of India's Govt and Rocky (who valorously emerges out of KGF slavery, as a Messiah)The film is narrated through the author's (Played by Anantnag) First hand experience to a News Editor (Played by Malvika Avinash) As his book gets banned by the Central Govt. He traces the journey of rocky from his birth to establishing himself as the feared crime lord from Mumbai docks to Bangalore to finally his destined place KGF. The mother sentiment is well crafted and placed appropriately throughout the film. Though the story line is predictable and replicates Ugramm template. In KGF also just like Ugramm, many characters get introduced and thus challenges one's memory to remember the count of characters. Yash's introduction in an elaborated action sequence keeps everyone engaged and makes glued to the screen. KGF falters at few places in the first half. Yash-Srinidhi scenes could have been better. The army of supporting characters may be revealed more in the Chapter 2. It's the second half, which meets the expectation and ends with retaliating climax, leaving multiple threads open only to be tied later in Chapter 2 on another day.KGF, from start to finish, is full of high octane action sequences, The dialogues are sharp and effective, Music is average, but gets compensated through an outrageous BGM (some influence from the soundtrack of Hams Zimmer's "The Oil"(Dunkirk).On Technical front: The captain of KGF mines, Prashant Neel, the Director should take a bow for bringing his vision on screen. Editing is very sharp, multiple scenes are played parallel and also intellectually blurred at few places to showcase that the character had no idea about the things to come. Ravi Basrur's music is a downer, but his BGM raises the milieu in all the sequences. The cinematography by Bhuvan Gowda is top-notch and world class (he will get all the awards if nominated functions PAN India level in 2019). The never say die attitude of Art Director Shivakumar should get all the accolades for erecting such massive sets of mines, in the midst of the dust bowls. KGF has used 90% of sets and just 10% of VFX for filming. KGF- Chapter 1 sets the stage for a macro-level showdown in chapter 2.
This is outright bad, and not even a "so bad its funny". Story, performance, background music, everything is awful.Not even worth watching out of curiosity.

reviews.review_title: Did I even watch the same movie as everyone else?
reviews.content: As I get older, I sometimes wonder if my brain wiring is becoming different from most people, which is bad news, because I can't trust movie reviews anymore. Take KGF, for example. SO. MUCH. HYPE! Like Baahubali level. Baahubali - although wasn't SOO spectacular, was at least entertaining. Moreover, we were watching a well-conceived historical fiction after a long time. So the hype was understandable. But KGF? Is this a joke or prank?To me, it seemed like the director got heavily awed after watching Mad Max, then decided to take certain "formulas" from Bahubali, and a few bits here and there from other films, and packaged it with a good trailer and decent BGM. But the overall story? Nothing new at all. A poor child vowing to become tough and strong due to poverty, joining a don gang and becoming a big shot goonda. I mean, how many countless movies have shown the same thing? It is an appealing story though - if taken at least with an ounce of logic. But no, one hero should be able to bash up 50 to 60 men single handedly! He can walk on petrol with a cigar lit, he can dodge a hundred bullets, he is GOD! He is Yash and he is a mass hero and he is GOD. When are we going to mature as an audience?Of course, a hero who kills pretty much in every second scene should also have a conscience right? Because we can't risk seeing a bad man as a hero. Oh no! So the hero stops traffic for miles and crosses the road - all for what? To give a bun to a poor lady and preach on the values of motherhood. See? We have a strong man AND a good man. So, worship him, please? Add to this a namesake hero worship song and a namesake heroine who first hates the hero and then adores him hearing his bun motherhood speech. Yawn.And did I mention - this story is so disjointed. In the name of experimentation, we reel from past to present to past, and it just gives a headache. The second half gets slightly better - but again, only because the bad guys are shown to be SO bad - like, literally monsters - that we want to see them defeated. The last ten minutes are so loud and violent that it took me a day to feel normal again. Moral of the story - I write long reviews that most people won't anyway agree with, but it feels good to vent.Hands down, the worst movie I have seen in 2018.

I will always be remembered this...........BRAVO

reviews.review_title: One of the lowest geades of movies I have ever seen
reviews.content:
The film has tasted my patience, and despite my whole hearted try to sit and watch for an anticipation of something good will come, I failed.
I remember, in year 2009, a movie came by the name "Agyat". Agyat was the most disappointing movie I have ever watched, until now. I have endured KGF for 45 minutes.
Amazed that some audiences has rated this movie over 8 out of 10. That's a shame. Some B'grade movies are actually far better than this.

This movie truly had the potential to be something more than just a bunch of braindead sequences of the protagonist beating up tens of hundreds of people at the same time with his bare hands, some even armed with guns.I mean, come on, seriously? The only intelligent confrontation scene was when the leading lady challenges Rocky, our hero, to touch her while she was encircled by her Gangster Daddy's bodyguard thugs. I half expected all the goons to lower their guns when Rocky stared at them or the guns to melt somehow. But thankfully, Rocky backs off, rides in a tanker with an inflammable liquid and then spills it all over the floor, thereby neutralizing the threat of ammunition being fired.You see, that was brains over brawn intelligent thinking. If only Rocky had used his brains more often than relying on his questionable source of strength with a seemingly endless reserve to get things done.The negative aspect of having an overpowered protagonist is that there isn't a moment that you're scared for his life. What if there's an army of bad guys coming at our hero? No problem, we've seen him kill or incapacitate hundreds of goons with his bare hands before, how hard could this new challenge possibly be? If you want a reference on how to get that balance right, please watch Marvel's Punisher on Netflix. Frank Castle kills numerous people at the same time too, but he takes a good thrashing himself in the process which makes him a believable character.The sets were good and the story really had potential. But, unfortunately, the Writer, Director, and Producers had already decided that this will be a no-brains, hero-worship flick with stylized explosions in the background while the protagonist walks in slow-motion with bad guys flying left and right and sometimes even spinning in the air after being struck as if they were cricket balls being hit out of the park. *sigh*1/10

reviews.review_title: An epic win for the Kannada film industry. KGF is a pan-Indian masterpiece.
reviews.content: I don't need to say that this film will set the Box Office down the southern states, on fire.But for the northern states, I'll have to say that please go and watch this movie if you love action dramas! This isn't a dull gangster movie or a long documentary, it's just intelligent, smart, stylish, stunning fun with a heart!KGF is a win for the whole Kannada film industry. Every single frame oozes a pan-Indian appeal. So no matter what language you watch it in, you'll get the feel of a straight film. Prashanth Neel's direction is stunning given that it's just his second directorial film. Yash is definitely the new pan-Indian star. His performance is beyond judging. The film is long in duration but I never realized that!Since it's a period action film, KGF delivers much more than what the trailers showed. It has action, adventure, drama and some suspense that will keep you glued till the end. It's neither funny nor too dark, and hence a properly balanced film. The dialogues are so crisp that I was literally smiling with excitement.Cinematography is mindblowing. The depiction of the Kolar Gold Fields is so stunning that you'll have a tough time finding an excuse for not watching it on the big screen. The action scenes were way above my expectations: each and every action sequence was phenomenally executed. Not many songs but all of them register big time.KGF isn't just for the Kannada-speaking people but for anyone who likes to watch action movies with a wholehearted execution. Once again, Hindi viewers, please don't regret later on when it'll be playing on TV and internet. Just go for it. As for me, I'll now watch more of Yash and Neel's filmography. I know I won't be the only one waiting for the second chapter of this epic.

1 Star because of the 8.2 overall rating.
To be frank, I loved the story and some dialogues. I don't know why people call this the "Best Action Movie in India". I mean, we can't actually see the action properly. All I could see was the hero swinging a hammer and people flying away.
And this is one of the worst edited movie ever. It has way too may cuts and shaky camera which makes it difficult to understand what's going on.
Yash is kind of perfect for this role. His acting was fine except for the romcom scenes. But I don't know if he is a good actor. It's impossible to judge his acting skills from this movie. There is an actress to love the hero. There are guys to praise the hero. It's basically the usual common man made to be a superhero.
But since the story felt interesting and BGM is terrific, I'm waiting for KGF 2.
Just watched it for 25-30 minutes. Waste of time and rating is misleading.

KGF is a One-Time Watch. KGF is a Fine Example of Marketing Strength in Film Industry. A Young Boy wants to be Rich & his Journey from Childhood to KGF (Gold Mine) is traced in Part 1. Lots of Characters, Lot of Production Budget, Lots of Style Yet IMDb Rating of 8.2. Shows how Manipulative & Powerful is Today's Digital World.Putting in Perspective,
1. Lead Actor: Honestly, If Growing Hair & Beard is Acting, then Sure "Yash Acting Was Superb". But, Yash was Stylish. That's the end !!! There wasn't much Acting required by Yash as was Style & Yash delivers on Style.
2. Actress & Songs: Actress are mere Audience Demand & Actor Ego Display in most Indian Movies & KGF isn't any Exception. The Lead Actress has no sense of Acting & it doesn't take a Drunkard to impress a High Society Girl as the Drunkard can beat 50 People without any scratch & has a "Sad" Backstory. Songs are placed for Style & does nothing to the Movie.
3. StoryLine: Almost Nil. Just enough Points to have sufficient Songs & Fight Scenes for Yash to engage in Style, Sorry Acting.
4. Production: High. Like Prabhas's Saaho, Money wasn't a concern & Production Values reflect Money Well Spent.
5. Direction: Good. Along with Production Values, Direction was directed towards Style.
6. Practicality: Zero. Fight Scenes & 1 Guy getting no Bullets yet his Bullets hitting many & Typical Macho Fight Scenes.KGF is Overrated at 8.2 in IMDb. Reminds me of Saaho yet KGF is a Gold Mine as compared to Saaho, which was a Disaster. 1 Time Watch & Entertaining.

Let me tell you first why there are so many one-starred reviews here. In India there is a concept of celebrity fans who love their chosen celebrities blindly, and any movie that hurt one of their loved-one's movie is automatically a hateful movie for them. And one of the most famous celebrity in India is Shahrukh Khan. As "K. G. F. Chapter 1" was released the same day Shahrukh's 'Zero' movie was released, which became a major flop against all odds, while competiting K. G. G, all true fans of Shahrukh Khan are obliged to post their 1-star reviews here. DO NOT take these reviews seriously. Just ignore them.This movie surely have something the haters of this movie claim. There is intense heroism. The Protagonist of this movie indeed has somewhat super-strength. He can beat twenty people in solo fighting. At times he's showed as invincible. Now, here is something very interesting. This same thing declared as major 'flaw' of the movie is what makes this movie simply great.Before I give the reason of 'how' and 'why' for my previous statement, let me clarify something here. Contrary to what many people believe, the protagonist in this movie named 'Rocky' is not entirely invincible. It's just that his weaknesses are not disclosed directly. If you're watching the movie closely, you will notice that he's extremely smart as well. He chooses the best scenarios for his fights. Sometimes he chooses right time for his fights. And sometimes he creates appropriate scenarios that provides him certain advantages. Those advantages can be darkness, fumes, etc., as well as intense fear among his opponents (as whenever he hits, he goes for a kill, which scare is enemies intensely). And in situations when he realizes he would be forced to fight in absence of such advantages, his facial expressions show his tension. Hence, he knows his strengths and weaknesses, and he fights considering those.Now let me come to the point that I mentioned earlier. Certain scripts require the protagonist to have unrealistic or unusual human strengths. Normally such movies are superhero movies. But there is also a category of movies which utilize the same concept for non-superhero protagonists. The main focus on such movies is not on how the protagonist have such strengths, but on what happens even when he has those strengths. The story is written accordingly. If you have watched Baahubali, you would understand what I mean by this.K. G. F., although a very different movie from Baahubali, also explores the same concept. The protagonist here is extremely strong. But what happens when he needs to go to a Gold Field and work as a slave (this is basic the description of the movie.) And this is the main story. Problem for many, however, has been that for them too much time was spent on the buildup on the main character and the movies' premise. Thing is, this movie is first part of a two-part movie. And total length of these two parts would be somewhere around 5.5 hours. So we can expect a buildup of 1 hour, which would be surely very long for some. But once passed, the movie would surely attached the viewer to the characters. And in my eyes the makers of this movie has surely done this with the most interesting way possible. They have brought several very interesting scenes, and have delivered several very exciting dialogues during this phase. Musical score also creates a very good impact during this phase.This movie is a piece of art for several reason. It would make you love a character who is cruel, immoral, mean, and a killer. At times you would want him to kill people, and when he won't, you will feel anger for him. Most important aspect of the movie is that it's not created with chronological scenes. Instead the story is being told non-linearly, with back and forth flashbacks, which at time would feel unconnected to the previous scene. But those scenes would surely deliver you an impact that would strengthen the character or premise in your mind. Certain joints of entirely different kind of dialogues will be spoken by entirely different people in entirely different timelines. Even more, dialogues of a different timeline or location and spoken by different people are used over special scenes, and some in slow motions. Extremely thoughtful smart plays are designed for some scenes that could have been done in most simplistic scenarios. Several times dialogues are left in the middle, and then scenes are used to explain further. All this increase the dramatic impact of those scenes and dialogues by many folds. This might might have not been done the first time. But I'm sure no other movie has ever done this with such greatness. I've instantly become a fan of this movie's director now.One more thing I would like to add. Although the premise and description of the movie would suggest this would be a brainless action film, this movie is far from it. There is intense emotional drama here. In fact, this emotional drama, between a mother and her son, plays even bigger role in the movie than the action part of the story. This is what sets up the main theme here, and its impact is kept throughout the movie by using several perfectly well-times flashbacks of the duo's interaction.I will highly recommend everyone to ignore all the negative reviews and watch this movie. And watch with open mind. Don't care too much about whether the laws of physics or unrealistic feeling fight sequences. Once the real story will start, these same things that were giving you somewhat irritations earlier would start giving you goosebumps. This movie surely deserves an average rating above 8 here at IMDB. And it has this for the right reasons.
Stay away if logic and common sense are important to you.

reviews.review_title: The Storm from Sandalwood is here
reviews.content: In 2014, we saw a new wave in Kannada Cinema by a newbie director named Prashant Neel. The movie Uggram, put the then struggling star SriMurali back on the success radar. Although the movie had a simple gangster plot, it stood out with its narration and the unique style of filmmaking. Almost 5 years after the director Neel is back with and how. With KGF, Prashant Neel has just put Kannada film industry back on the map. This most expensive Kannada movie has been simultaneously released in 5 languages and rightly so as it is a movie not to be missed.I'd rather not brief about the story. The movie is divided into two halves. The first half is about the shenanigans of the quirky badass gangster (or should I say monster?) Rocky Bhai. The second half has a much dark tone to it along with the build up to the Chapter 2. There is not too much to read into the script. But this time around the director Prashant Neel has corrected the mistakes that he had made with his previous venture Uggram. The editing is crisp, there aren't any unnecessary comedy bits or romance. The songs are well placed and the music Ravi Barsur really helps with the goosebumps. Although the camera moves very fast in the action sequences, they are not over the top unlike most movies. The slo mo shots as shown in the trailer really up the serious tone of the movie. There are also some surprise elements in the screenplay which is very new to Indian cinema. After a long time in Kannada cinema I have seen a movie with such good dialogue writing. The tone of the dialogues shift according to the scenarios, while they have lighter and mass appeal while addressing the lead character and they shift to a poetic tone with the narration. It is unfair not to mention the art and the costume department who have really worked hard to make this period film. The extensive use of sets, close up shots and the colour tone of the movie has worked out well for Neel to make it look like a proper period film.I have never been much of a Yash fan, but boy has he done justice to this role. He both overplays and underplays the character Rocky to perfection and no wonder he spent close to 3 years for this movie. He also fills in for the comedy part of the movie with great delivery of one liners. Big credit to the director to have given some new Kannada actors a chance instead of importing villains from other industries. Female lead Sreenidhi Shetty looks very beautiful and has done justice for a debutant. Hopefully we will get to see more of Vasishta Simha and Achyut Kumar in Chapter 2. Many other veteran Kannada actors like Anathnag, B Suresh, Malavika and the list goes on who have played key roles with less screen time. Some of the actors' appearance in the screen adds to the nostalgia factor.KGF finally shows that a movie can live up to the hype it creates. The movie might not have an extraordinary story line but it is the movie which can make every Kannadiga and an Indian proud. Go watch for the entertainment, goosebumps, acting and more importantly the art of film making.

I went to this movie instead of zero because of SE Rajamouli's endorsement and I was not disappointed. It should have really been a sequel to the original Agneepath. I would say the perfect masala movie. I found the non linear narration sequence a little jarring but the director almost seems to cover his shortcomings with reference to the tautness of the screenplay by using Anant Nag ( narrators) possible Alzheimer's. The sequence where the hero in the process of wooing his girl gets distracted possibly by a scene from his own childhood is absolutely Gold or should I say kolar gold. A must watch for any 80s and 90s action buffs. This ranks with Venkatesh's Shatruvu, Amitabhs Agneepath, and Sanjay Dutts Aatish. It is also heavily inspired by the first part of Baahubali. Perfect kichdi and more power to his sequel.

Great cinematography, shots and sound production. I had no idea who Yash was before watching this but his acting is really good. the action really is good as is more realistic and not absolutely absurd as per the norm of other Southern movies.
The plot is great and the story reaaly builds up to an epic chapter 2.
I've got to say that all the characters in the movie with the similar long beards and flowing ribs make them look similar. i had to constantly check upon X Ray too understand who the character is. I felt that the romance between Rocky and Reena and the scene in Bangalore is totally pointless and kinda takes you away from the original plot. But the original script is amazing and will look forward to next movie.

reviews.review_title: A kind of story telling like in Bahubali (despite low budget).
reviews.content: When I first encountered the trailer I started comparing it with Gangs of Wasseypur. The reason was there it was story started with coal mines and here Gold mines were mentioned.After watching the movie however I got to know K.G.F. to be a kind of different movie. A movie based on a hero (or a villain).Here in the first installment, what I liked most was the mother - child take on relation between them. It shook's your emotions on more than one instance. I also liked Rocky's character may it be as a child or as an adult. The other thing that followed my liking was the story, the way how it avoided being goofy.Final Verdict: It would not be wrong if I say it a kind of story telling like in Bahubali. It is that good even with comparatively low budget. If that's the reason for you to watch Bahubali go and watch this one as well.

reviews.review_title: KGF strikes a Golden haul for Sandalwood!
reviews.content: The story begins with Anant Nag unveiling the secret story of Kolar Gold Fields to a journalist Malavika Avinash. Growing up on the streets of Mumbai, Rocky goes to the blood ravaged mine fields of Kolara in Karnataka as a slave, and goes on to take control. Yash has acted very maturely throughout the movie. His hairstyle, looks and fighting scenes are the striking features of the film. The cinematography is realistic, whether it is the dark blood ravaged fields of Kolara or the nightlife in Mumbai & Bengaluru, it will definitely impress the viewer. Prashanth Neel has directed the movie brilliantly. Ravi Basrur's music deserves a special mention. The music is very sophisticated and also gives liveliness to the film. All the songs give you goosebumps when you listen to it! This film takes Sandalwood almost close to the level of Hollywood and is bound to make a mark across Indian cinema!#KGF #Sandalwood

reviews.review_title: Hyperviolent mass masala SCARFACE meets MAD MAX FURY ROAD
reviews.content:
Plot: Angry young orphan with flashbacks of his late mother's motivational dialogues tries to climb up the crime ladder and free slaves single handedly.
Pros: Excellent cinematography and background score, good production design, good editing but becomes repetitive with the flashbacks.
Cons: Same old story, writing is bad, hyperviolent, masala mass illogical fights, thugs run in groups towards the hero to get beaten up, high body count, cliché villains, bullets don't touch the hero, silly hilarious mass dialogues like "If you are bad, I'm your dad.", "He is not a gangster, he is a monster." "Now i don't want kushka, i want biryani." ,Heroine role is meaningless, full film is buildup and hype for the hero, very lengthy running time.Ending is copied from human sacrifice scene of APOCALYPTO and last scene is from APOCALYPSE NOW.Overall conclusion: Definitely OVERRATED by others. If you like above things can watch one time. If not, avoid it.

If the move was trimmed and the choppy sequences and unnecessary narrations removed it would be less than a one hour movie.There is an overload of characters whose purpose is not clear. Lot of them look alike. There is unnecessary mother-son emotions thrust at various points, which becomes unbearable. Copard to this the movie Pushpa has very smooth flow and keeps you curious and forces you to keep watching. With KGF I felt like switching off the movie. I hope the part 2 is better and storyline is much tighter.

When the going gets tough, people start searching for a hero who would stand up for them and liberate them from all the pain and difficulties that they have been forced to endure. Stories of heroism have always been loved by the viewers, but the impact of such films become even bigger when people are going through a rough phase in their real life, and the movie ends up offering them a cathartic release. In the 1970's, India was going through a difficult phase economically, people were struggling to make ends meet; at that time Amitabh Bachchan's films became the voice of the people and because of the characters he was playing, he was often called as the angry young man. He was the hero, who stood up against the system that was crushing the common man with its policies and making their lives difficult. People look up to such heroes, because they give them hope for a better future; they see such heroes as the answer to their prayers; that optimism gives them the strength to stand up and fight again. Through KGF, Director Prashant Neel has made an attempt to recreate a similar kind of story, where the lead character is nothing less than a messiah for everyone.KGF is a movie that has been designed to give you goosebumps. The powerful dialogues by Prashant Neel, electrifying music by Ravi Basrur and swag of lead actor Yash is bound to fill your heart with so many emotions that you might be tempted to stand up and cheer for the hero and give him a shout out. This is the kind of film that makes you feel alive and ready to conquer the world. The director succeeds in making a connection with the audience and triggering all the right emotions inside them.KGF is not the first action or gangster film, but it manages to strike a chord with it's viewers like no other film because the story of this film is not that of a mindless criminal who indulges in violence for no reason at all, but instead of a boy who rises up to be a powerful force after facing a thousand hardships himself. This is the kind of story that people really associate with, because they see themselves in that hero. KGF gives the audience a hero they can truly believe in, a hero who genuinely understands the pain of the people because he has suffered it all himself. With so much injustice around us in the real world, when you see someone like Rocky standing up to fight against the evil, it feels cathartic.Actor Yash was truly born to play this role; I can't imagine any other actor to play this character. The creative team has done an absolutely stupendous job in creating the look of Rocky; it's not common for actors to sport such a long beard and thick hair, but Yash totally owns this look. Every time he appears on screen, he stands out from everyone else; every time he disappears from the screen, you want him to come back soon, that's how powerful an impact he makes with his presence. Looks and physical presence are not the only aspects nailed by Yash; the actor comes across as extremely believable every time he says a dialogue. In today's era, very few actors look as charismatic as Yash does on screen; he is easily one of the best looking actors of the Indian Film Industry.Action movies are known primarily for their action only, but KGF is quite different because it's also an emotional roller coaster. In the 1970's, mother's love was a basic ingredient in almost every film, and since director Prashant Neel is heavily inspired from that era, he has added a sub plot involving Rocky's mother and her tragic life. For Indians, there is no other human being who matters more to them than their mother; fully aware of this reality, director Prashant Neel has aimed directly at the heart of all Indians. Some of the most heartfelt scenes and dialogues of the film involve either Rocky's mother or when he remembers his mother. The dialogue writer deserves a lot of appreciation for writing some extremely beautiful dialogues. The final dialogue itself, spoken by Rocky's mother, deserves a separate award because of how powerful it is and the amount of goosebumps it evokes.More often than not movies start losing their grip in the second half, but KGF becomes a whole new monster in the second half as the story reaches the Kolar Gold Fields. The screenplay of the second half is even more engaging than the first half. The pacing never feels off as you are totally intrigued by the proceedings. This is what sets apart KGF from regular action movies; Prashant Neel has given this film a well layered story with its fair share of twists and turns that never allow your interest to fade away.The visuals of the film are absolutely stunning. The art direction team and the cinematographer have done a tremendous job in giving life to this world and presenting it to us in such a beautiful and realistic manner. The action sequences of the film won't give you a headache because they have been choreographed very stylishly.One of the strongest support that this movie gets is from music composer Ravi Basrur, who has created some heartfelt as well as electrifying songs for the film. The song of the mother, Garbadhi, will stay with you long after you have finished watching the film. Ravi Basrur has most certainly left a big impression with his work in this film and I would be definitely looking forward to what kind of music he composes in the future.On paper, KGF is just an action film; but in reality it's so much more than that. KGF is an absolute must watch for everyone who wishes to experience pure unadulterated joy, happiness, goosebumps and adrenaline rush.

KGF feels like almost every masala film from the 90s and 00s. The raison d'etre for the film's supporting characters is to sing praises about the immortal, brute of a protagonist. So, whenever I see someone talking about Rocky, the protagonist in KGF, I predict a mass intro scene and "surprise, surprise", there it is. I had the same issue with Maari and the countless times we are introduced to Dhanush like we've never seen him before.KGF is technically strong. Sadly, that's the only thing the movie is good at. It felt like the time I watched the ill-fated Bheema, which had some incredibly strong cinematography. But, Bheema had nothing else. KGF too, has nothing else. The story is one that we've all been accustomed to. The second half of the movie actually reminded me of the second half of Kuruvi.I'm trying to avoid spoilers here. So, let's see how much of the story I can share with you. Rocky is born in a desperately poor family. How desperate? His dying mother tells him "whatever you do, become rich." So much for childhood trauma. Everything he does after this scene is to become rich.What I liked was that there was not a single frame where the characters could relax for a bit. It was all onward and upward to action city. In a movie like this, no one gets a breather. Neither the characters nor the audience. I was disappointed with the film because I wasn't engaged in the story. The screenplay is weak. Since this is "Chapter 1", I'm assuming that the vast majority of empty characters in this movie will have something to do in the sequel. If not, that's a waste of time for us for buying into these characters.I'm okay with the macho, immortal portrayal of Rocky. But, there's nothing new about him. You can take any character from past films such as Temper, Petta, Baasha or even Sarrainodu. You'll find these characters to be wildly entertaining. Rocky however isn't all that. He's grim and brooding. Even when he's supposed to be romancing the girl, he's just awkward. Heaven knows how the romantic angle worked out in this film.My final verdict is that this film is all pomp and no show, all style and no substance. You can tell a filmmaker's style by watching one or more of his films. I've seen parts of Uggram and the whole of KGF Chapter 1. I don't know what Prashant Neel is about. Is he trying to be the next Michael Bay or does he aspire to be Sergio Leone? Neutral colours isn't an aesthetic that can carry an entire film. You need sparks of vividity, Prashant. Make a better film next time. With better writing, settings and well etched out characters.

reviews.review_title: Not so appealing but good elevation
reviews.content:
Movie runs in flashback mode where a senior journalist talks about India's most dangerous criminal and his life story . It's all about his struggles, challenges he faced to be rich from utmost poor. For this the challenge and opportunity he gets is killing mafia don in Karnataka who is ruling KGF while Rocky (Yash) is also a rowdy in Mumbai
Story is something not very new but proceedings are shown stylish on one hand and raw rustic on other hand which is highlight in the movie. Yash acting is very stylish and action episodes though exaggerating are entertaining especially in 2nd half.
The sufferings of people in KGF are shown raw and rustic which might be difficult to go with a section of audience. 1st half completely relies on hero characterisation and unnecessary fights, elevation sequences. No importance to female lead. Certain episodes are too exaggerating. Dialogues are long and confusing with unnecessary flash movements and sequences and background score in middle of conversations. Too much conversations and details are said when movie is processing which is not clear and irritates at some points while the same is said in climax portion simply which can be done at that time of movie portion instead of long dialogues or completely avoid those dialogues on that movements making audience to have more suspense in proceedings and reveal it in climax.
While in 2nd half story picks up in KGF too much dialogues in middle disturb flow and makes boring. While these episodes are more rustic there is more scope of hero elevation . That unnecessary elevation in 1st half could be used here for better treatment. However it had flavor of Telugu film Chatrapati and same kind of elevation but there is no rajamouli,prabhas here so punch is little low compared with that film.
Still climax hero elevation scenes where Rocky fights against goons is highlight part of movie as until then their sufferings shown in very unpleasant way which will be enjoyed by B,C center audience. But as I mentioned before these scenes can be elevated even more like Chatrapati which had same flavor.
Then the final part when Rocky takes don position of KGF by killing present don is flat and hurried where again hero elevation is required more but it's not present.
There comes explanation to all the plans of Rocky to conquer KGF and beginning of chapter 2.
Overall movie is boring at many parts and exaggerating at many parts
But elevation scenes ,fights,style workout too which makes this flick a hard one time watch

reviews.review_title: Actions without logic, Story without sense!!
reviews.content: Story- Movie starts with the introduction of a brave-hearted boy who on his mother's command wants to conquer the world and be the richest whichever is possible. He starts to follow his goal in Mumbai with nothing in terms of wealth but is himself god-gifted in terms of man-power. He wants to build a brand of his name- "Rocky" as seen on his bike. In after-sequences, he is shown to defeat every gangsters of mumbai with a mighty force of local ruffians single-handedly. Seeing this he is then called to Bangalore by one of the biggest crimelord there named Rajendra Desai for a seemingly impossible mission. He is assigned a task of assassinating the violent and cruel successor of Konar Gold Field's previous emporer- Garuda in the DYSS headquarters, where he fails to kill Garuda due to the presence of large number of armed guards. But then he enters Kolar gold mines alone breaking the highest security to reach Garuda and eventually becomes successful to kill Garuda surpassing all those thousand armed men protecting Garuda. "Overall the plot is too weak and quite illogical".Action scenes- The protagonist is shown to be unstoppable and almighty as can be seen in any typical South Indian movies. Here also action surpasses logic. Rocky alone is able to defeat hundred men equipped with weapons. What more worse is he infiltrates the palace heavily guarded by the almost thousands of trained servicemen without pre-planning and anyone's help. How he has got these powers is a mystery though. "Action scenes are very unreal and out of mind".Direction- The scenes in the movie are changing so fast that they interfere with the continuity of watching movie and eventually bereave the interest of spectators. Most of the scenes are shot in low light and the story is progressing so rapidly that it feels the mind with the sense of impracticable and unemotional things. "The direction is the greatest downside of the movie".Final Words- "The film is not up to the mark. The story has no firm base. It is not explained that how Rocky became so powerful and popular from a harsh poverty. Characters of don are continuously changing in the first half. The sequences in the film are also illogically arranged. Oveall experience is very unrealistic and poor. There is a need of much more improvement in KGF Chapter 2."

reviews.review_title: From 1 to an 8 directly. Language makes a difference.
reviews.content: When I first watched this move, I found it hard to take it seriously. The dialogues seemed corny, voices seemed hammy and the story felt nonsensical.I realised this movie's true potential only when I decided to watch it again. But the second time round it had to be in the original language because that's the director's vision which I wanted to know. And oh boy how different it was then. A completely different film if I may.This is because the first Time around, I had watched it in Hindi. The dubbing artist did a really atrocious job. He sounded like a fool if I may. Which is why I wasn't able to take this movie seriously at all. The dub just doesn't have that impact that the original version has. I don't know how they settled for such a hammy actor. Go through the broken English dialogues. I swear you will cringe rather than laugh.Talking about the film, the story is great, cinematography and direction, credit to Prashant Neel, it is absolutely grand. BGM is the life of this film. Such hardcore BGM just elevates this film to a different level. But the main best thing about this movie is the hero. Yash is an absolute hero. What a look, what great acting skills he possesses and an insane physique which allows him to carry out the action scenes with total ease. He fits the role of Rocky perfectly and his some serious swagger. I loved his dialogue delivery. Credit to the dialogue writer and also Yash who delivers them to perfection. The dialogues give you an insane feel and I can imagine watching This film in Kannada and cheering and hooting at the dialogues. Kannadigas must o have surely had a blast. The Hindi fellow ruined such amazing dialogues and all he got from at least me was embarrassed expressions. However the dialogues in Kannada said by Yash gave me a feel that I cannot express in words.Kudos to Kannada film industry for making this absolutely wonderful movie. I'm team KGF now and completely stoked for chapter 2.

Quite ashamed that this is the film is made in the Kannada industry for the world stage. If you have a brain leave it at home, also leave your ears and eyes. The guards and "villains" are shown as if they are demons from a mythological book laughing loudly ALL the time and fighting to be the one to kill. I swear the high reviews look manufactured or just hype building on top of the other.

I went to watch this movie day before yesterday with a friend.I saw this movie with a hope that it has a good storyline and my god.....it was 3 hours of complete torture.
I believed the audience and social media reviews saying it was an outstanding film like the Baahubali franchise..I guess I fell into a huge pitfall trap.
The 3-hour torturous film is completely filled with mindless action sequences...inane,boring dialogues and hammy acting by the principal characters.
As far as the story is concerned..(the main reason why I wanted to watch the movie in the first place)...it is unoriginal and waferthin.
The entire first half of the movie is a gangster caper thriller,certain parts of the movie were lifted from Mani Ratnam's classic,Nayagan,especially the first half.There were no surprises at all..it offered nothing new
The second half is what makes the film even worse...the main reason..is the horrible editing.This is also where the film completely loses track of the storyline..and at one point,you feel that you're playing a video game..where the only objective of the player is to kill bad guys..it's kind of like God Of War.
Yash,the lead protagonist gives a hamming performance,he only hits and kills people with no rime or reason,Srinidhi Shetty is average.Anant Nag is wonderful in his supporting role,however.
In short,KGF is two movies in one..in the first half..it is a gangster movie,in the second..a gory video game with horrible editing that is bound to give you epileptic seizures.I know the audience is loving it but I am really sorry to say I was disappointed.
I am going with two out of ten for this movie.
However..considering the movie is a huge success now and audiences are loving it..the film will give recognition to the Kannada film industry outside Karnataka.

reviews.review_title: Chapter 1 sets the stage for a Macro level showdown in Chapter 2.
reviews.content: What's Passion? To work or put efforts on something repeatedly until you get it absolutely right, which one loves and holds close to the heart without getting distracted even for a second. In one of the interviews Prashant Neel, the Director had said that he has watched KGF more than 150 times while editing. He wanted to make his KGF, a near perfect craft. While shooting, Bhuvan Gowda, the cinematographer used to carry around 40kgs of the camera and its accessories on top while canning the sequences in windy and dusty region. The gigantic sets used to come down crashing after heavy wind and rains yet the Art Director, Shivakumar used to go back in erecting the same sets as they stood earlier. Yash, used to give multiple retakes with no sign of fatigue or feeling bored in that dust bowl.KGF will be made in two chapters. The chapter 1 is out and at the outset, it traces with pre-historical chronology world of events letting the audience know the importance of owning Gold and the battles for it. The chapter 1 deals with micro level of unorganized crime, Mafia and underworld. The Chapter 1 depicts about the greed and the race for one-up man-ship within many characters in getting the control of Goldmine, KGF. To enter into the Macro level of an orbit of world crime syndicate, one has to clear his way at the micro level. The dirt has to be cleaned to make way to the top. The chapter 1 ends at the doorstep of Chapter 2, which is meant to open for the Triangular battle between International mafia (for Gold), The interruption of India's Govt and Rocky (who valorously emerges out of KGF slavery, as a Messiah)The film is narrated through the author's (Played by Anantnag) First hand experience to a News Editor (Played by Malvika Avinash) As his book gets banned by the Central Govt. He traces the journey of rocky from his birth to establishing himself as the feared crime lord from Mumbai docks to Bangalore to finally his destined place KGF. The mother sentiment is well crafted and placed appropriately throughout the film. Though the story line is predictable and replicates Ugramm template. In KGF also just like Ugramm, many characters get introduced and thus challenges one's memory to remember the count of characters. Yash's introduction in an elaborated action sequence keeps everyone engaged and makes glued to the screen. KGF falters at few places in the first half. Yash-Srinidhi scenes could have been better. The army of supporting characters may be revealed more in the Chapter 2. It's the second half, which meets the expectation and ends with retaliating climax, leaving multiple threads open only to be tied later in Chapter 2 on another day.KGF, from start to finish, is full of high octane action sequences, The dialogues are sharp and effective, Music is average, but gets compensated through an outrageous BGM (some influence from the soundtrack of Hams Zimmer's "The Oil"(Dunkirk).On Technical front: The captain of KGF mines, Prashant Neel, the Director should take a bow for bringing his vision on screen. Editing is very sharp, multiple scenes are played parallel and also intellectually blurred at few places to showcase that the character had no idea about the things to come. Ravi Basrur's music is a downer, but his BGM raises the milieu in all the sequences. The cinematography by Bhuvan Gowda is top-notch and world class (he will get all the awards if nominated functions PAN India level in 2019). The never say die attitude of Art Director Shivakumar should get all the accolades for erecting such massive sets of mines, in the midst of the dust bowls. KGF has used 90% of sets and just 10% of VFX for filming. KGF- Chapter 1 sets the stage for a macro-level showdown in chapter 2.

reviews.review_title: Powerful People Comes From Powerful Places
reviews.content:
How many movies we know, that has a protagonist who digs his way to the top, through the land of greed, money and power? Hmm.., a lot isn't it!. Oh., ya it's a universal concept.
But how many movies showed the journey of the protagonist through every single frame, through every single character? This is what you can expect from this trending blockbuster KGF.The tale of a hero, told through every single character that impacts the next scene in the film. I guess, Director unofficially took a new story telling technique breaking the fourth wall of Filmmaking. Believable story, Brilliant visuals, sharp editing and riveting climax sequence sets right beginning for the 2nd part.Epilogue: It's time to stop comparing Indian movies to Hollywood. We got ourselves a bunch of exceptional storytellers who goes beyond the edge.

KGF CHAPTER-1 ..Is Not a One story.. it is massive linked stories of getting POWER...it's absolutely stunning film...inside..movie villains are like are heroes... they nailed it with performance.. and each and every Frames of movie story tells us... YOU WILL ENGAGE UNTIL END..no..no..no!!..you will CURIOUS... and MINING part Visualization is stunning ..and..fears you..# I never saw like this in any movie.. @ last overall my Rating: - 10/10##POSITIVES:# YASH..extraordinary attitude..and action sequence..10/10
#srinidhi.. extraordinary attitude ..rich girl..10/10
# villains ..i don't know names..but they are absolute heroes in this cinema..10/10
#ananth nag.. good voice and good story telling...10/10
# cinematography..bhuvan gowda..nailed it with camera...10/10
#music..songs are super and very related to story..background music stunning...9/10
# direction.. - introducing characters and showing...them is.. extraordinary..screenplay..is stunning..#story telling is a..bit different...and .. use of JUNIOR artists ..is extraordinary ..and mining part is very good... also set is fantastic..9/10##NAGATIVES: WHY I GAVE 9/10..to direction and others...you have to see in theaters...

A Masterpiece!!

This movie shows where Sandalwood stands and has always stood! It just makes one so proud!The phrase that strikes one's mind on hearing the word KGF is Gold Mines. Well, time to redefine that!!
It's time for the Gold class and gold mass!!
What a movie!! Top notch acting cinematography screenplay dialogues etc etc ..Yash has surpassed himself in every scene. An actor who has immense potential, you tap it and you have a character called Rocky!! Salaam Rocky indeed!What sets the hero apart from other story heros is that he is not too emotional or sentimental but plans for the greater good, is not consumed by everything happening. This shows so clearly when he is almost annoyed when people start looking towards him as their deliverer.Death of the mother-son scene, that guy who begs for deliverance and escape, and sacrifices himself for his wife and yet to be born baby is soo heart touching!!
That scene with the old man running around feeling his death nearing him is soo fear inducing, you can't stop yourself from feeling it so close. Also the girl baby birth scene is just so overwhelming.
Just when you think one scene is the best you have another..seems every scene competes with others to be the best..that makes the movie a winner..a complete one..period!!
The climax is one hell of a scene.. that dialogue the Mother says about leadership is what takes the movie to another level..Just when you think the movie has reached its zenith with the fast paced script and excellent visuals you'd feel the only lag is music. Would've loved a more haunting and memorable humming for the intense scenes (likes of Ugram and Tagaru). The sentimental music is very good. Songs were a little disappointing.
Hope the music is improved in the chapter 2.
Also the English subtitles were a little awkward at places, they were not translated correctly in more than one scene.not sure if this is got to do with the different files used or whatever.Bestest part is the BELIEVABLE action scenes which are really great. "Aaa Obba, That One Man!! ". Most of the action movies tend to exaggerate the stunts to ridiculous squabbles, thankfully here they're terrific and so very believable.Can't wait for the second chapter..seeing they've set the benchmark so high in the very first!! Wish them all good luck for the next part!!

reviews.review_title: Pathetic first half, phenomenal second half
reviews.content: I know, many people will mark this review unhelpful when Chapter 2 comes closer to release. But honestly those toxic fans are the reason why my hopes from this film were so high. When the trailer for KGF: Chapter 2 came, many people were saying that this film will mark the end of Bollywood. I saw KGF: Chapter 1 hoping that this film will be something like Baahubali (without the CGI of course). But no, this isn't any different from any normal South Indian film. In fact, it is pretty much what everyone hates about Bollywood. It has eve teasing, corrupt politicians, peaceful religion shown as good people and Hindus shown as bad people, unrealistic action and item songs.The film begins by mentioning Rocky (of course, the most unique name for a hero) is the most wanted criminal in Indian history, and yet there is nowhere that his account has been mentioned. Now I have several questions. How come one book is the only source of the people knowing about the biggest criminal to ever exist? How come no one else wrote about it? I'm 99% sure there must have been some Ravish Kumars or Arnab Goswamis at the time who would write this down at least in secret. And what about the TV channels who must have accidentally aired it before it was announced that it has to be a secret? And what about international news sources? If they can write about Dawood Ibrahim, why not about this? But anyway, let's not get carried away by just one illogical thing. There are a dozen more to come.Now, Rocky had been told in his childhood by his dying mother that he has to become the richest and the most powerful person in the world, and that's what he sets out to do. Except there is one problem - he doesn't even know what the most powerful position is. He goes in the side of the underworld and tries his best to establish himself over there, while the UN secretary-general probably laughs in the corner. Also keep in mind that the UN secretary-general is only the most powerful person in the world, not the richest. So now he has to get to a position without looking suspiciously rich. But don't worry about that, because Rocky is too busy singing Happy Birthday while killing bad guys.Speaking of killing bad guys, everytime Rocky fights, there are always like, a dozen jump cuts and lights flickering. He can kill his enemies and his audience who suffer from epileptic seizures. And speaking of epileptic seizures, let's play the drinking game. Every time the screen blacks out, you take one sip. By the end of the film you won't have enough space in your body to insert more liquid. Good luck in the toilet. And speaking of drinking, of course no South Indian film can be completed without harassing or verbally abusing a woman till she gives in. So there is the villain's daughter who is drinking in the public after blocking the road (it looked like a cheap parody of Watchmen). Now I don't know if the Hindi dubbing was so horrendous or the dialogues were actually so bad, but our hero starts speaking gibberish while beating her henchmen.But once the second half starts the film gets much better. Rocky goes inside KGF, and that is where the big story starts. At that point I have no complaints. In fact, it is where the film shows why it is so popular. However, there also some of the cinematography problems do exist, like the bad camera angles, quick jump cuts and of course, the screen going black. But the selling point of the film is the colour grading. That has been done very well, to the point that some scenes look like perfect desktop wallpapers. The ending looked very iconic, something that one will remember while leaving the theatre.The ideas used in this film are very good. From showing how Rocky goes ahead to touch the heroine while ensuring that the henchmen don't shoot him, to arranging the gun for the minister's murder - everything seemed unique, even if it was predictable at some points. The action is pretty much the same as any other South Indian film, and that is what makes it fun to watch. This is one thing that I find very annoying about Bollywood; it is trying to look as realistic as possible nowadays, because of which it feels like a washerman's dog. And I guess this is probably what all those people were talking about when they said this is better than most of Bollywood nowadays.I'd definitely look forward to Chapter 2 when it comes, because of how much suspense it built up in the end. It doesn't end with a question like why Katappa killed Baahubali, but rather one like what will happen next. Although it is pretty obvious what is going to happen next, let's be honest. None of us are in for the story. We just want to see some of that Yash.

reviews.review_title: Spectacular movie with great story line
reviews.content: Must watch it . It's a universal concept and every one will sure enjoy it

Background Score of KGF is commendable. But songs did lack the essence of liking. DoP should be applauded and praised after the recreational hit. The VFX was limited but not at all bad. The movie remained dark in the second part but carried tone of the movie. The delivery of dialogues and screenplay were well punched. The writers efforts could easily be seen over the screen. The best art were analogies and poems used within. Archana Jois gave a splendid performance playing Rocky's mother, a strong feminist performace and very strong character as well as supporting role. Rocky played by Yash is potrayal of Sorrow, Anger, Heroism and Peace artform. Character is well written bit superbly potrayed. Srinidhi Shetty plays love interest of Rocky but fails to make an impactful performance. Mouni Roy in cameo appearence, adds glamour in her short screen time. Direction came as an icing to the cake where the storyline played at various timelines was so intense, that it developed a sense of enjoyment for 200 minutes of plessure.

I went to the movie with minimal expectations. I know the viewership of kannada movies and budget they can afford. However, I went to this movie for a premiere show in USA, which is rare to happen for a kannada movie. Usually the process is kannada movie does well in India, then it get released in USA.This movie is beyond all the expectations. Wonderful storytelling, superb direction and camera work and above all the actors. Yash rocks as 'Rocky', he is a meagastar.

reviews.review_title: A only movie made me sleep

A movie box office-250cr,after releasing it in 4 languages. I watched this movie because my cousin told me,no popularity of this movie. I started watching movie then I get known that this movie is going to be full of goons,which is easiest topic to write story. But I continued. Later the boy named Yash grows,he get confidence and hairstyle! I thought he would entertain me but he just did fight of 2 minutes and over acting of talking. Then he meet a girl,show attitude and go. Later some big beared boring people bores more because they were usless. Biggest Problem was the cameraman,he even could not do a scene for longer than 2 seconds. Which was making me more sleepy.Then after a song came,which was looking in Hindi actually,I surprised that how Kannad film made Hindi song. But I get known that the item song was made specially for Hindi audience. Total waste of creativity actually. Later I was literally bored and I was skipping a movie for first time! The gold mines and labor in the presence of Indian government,What logic is this?Later I was eagerlly waiting for fight then in the mine Yash started a blackout fight,I didn't get how he did it,I mean fighting in dark mines!!Then again only Sultan Sultan could be heard. Over acting of each and every labor. At last,something very logical is seen,Yash kill a boss person with help of teleporting. But I never got known expect Yash,what other person has role?Overall,some scene (at last)made to not enjoy this fight. For 4 second we see Yash,them for other 4 sec we see a crying baby.scene that made me too disappointed was person is telling story of these,we were not be connected to movie,whole movie was told to us.Overall This movie was
Story : 3/10. Direction : 5/10 Acting: 2/10 Visual:7/10 Ideas : 6/10there was no kissing or sex scene,I really appreciate this.

reviews.review_title: A greatest action movie that we will remember for a long time.
reviews.content:
I saw this Movie in Halifax, a remote east coast city of Canada. That itself is an achievement of sort for this movie. No Kannada cinema has been screened here before ever. I went to the movie with assuming some kind of assumptions and expectations about the heroism and the movie. However, within moments I started watching understood that this is no simple film. The complex narration gives that extra edge and keeps you hooked onto the screens until the last moment. The non-linear 3rd person presentation of the facts as well as struck solid GOLD. The cinematography is top notch HOLLYWOOD standard while background music and symphony elements are mind blowing.
Follow each and every dialog carefully, if you miss you may struggle to follow.
If you have not watched the movie yet, go watch now.
This movie will be remembered for a long time.

reviews.review_title: Another Bahubali has arrived at Cinema halls without Kattapa. Do visit him.
reviews.content: Direction: Prashanth Neel has taken huge risk in his second outing with KGF. He can be consider as visionary director after S.S. Rajamaouli and S.Shankar. First half dedicated to image builder for Yash and Second half for execution. Good thing about direction, Prashanth switched brilliantly from super fast action sequence with gangster war to Leader of weak people from Gold Mines.Performance: Yash is sure shot the star performer of this first chapter. Since from the beginning, he carried the momentum and he has all abilities to become next Bahubali of Indian cinema. I feel bad that Srinidhi Shetty did not get enough frame. Ramachandra Raju as Garuda look like Devil and perfect villain for chapter 1.Script: Story is really engaging and entertaining and credit goes to once again captain Prashanth Neel. He used teaching from mother as the way for hero's target in the life. Killing of innocents in Kolar Gold mines used as get link for killing of evil guards in front of all public. Even climax was really great but it failed to triggered wave of curiosity like Bahubali: Beginning.Dialogues: Action movie need good dialogue so that people can enjoy the action sequences with more entertainment.It is really good to see great dialogues in Hindi dubbed version. e.g. "Duniya ki sarvshreshth Yoddha Maa hoti hain"(Translate: Mother is the greatest warrior of the world).Music and Background Score: There was two songs present in Hindi dubbed version. First one was Salaam Rocky Bhai which remind you soundtrack from Bahubali. Second one was Item song by Mouni Roy. Music can be better for Hindi version as we missed music like Bahubali Series. Background score was really impressive one.Box-office: On Day 1, Zero has earned 20 crores and KGF has earned 18 crores due to less number of screen counts. This figure may be change in coming days or week due to better words of mouth.Last Words: This movie can be better plan to celebrate Christmas with your family and friends.
This is insane movie that can beat every record. One of the best movie i ever watch. It's Dialogue are so insane.Yash is amazing.I am waiting for Chapter 2.

This is my second Kannada movie after Ugramm
which happens to be directed by the same director as of K.G.F.!
K.G.F. is a movie we've all been waiting for the ages!
Prashanth Neel, Kudos sir!

A Masterpiece!!
Congratulations to the whole team.. A heartfelt standing ovation too!!
This movie shows where Sandalwood stands and has always stood! It just makes one so proud!Ananth Nag Sir, hats off to this legendary actor. He makes you feel (and not just see and hear) the story in his own way.
Yash has surpassed himself in every scene. An actor who has immense potential, you tap it and you have a character called Rocky!! Salaam Rocky indeed!The first half is filled up with lots of characters and stories..the narration was a little fast there. The second half is brilliant, action packed, emotions sentiments and what not!! Hindi being used in first half is fine with the region the story set in. I found the heroines dialogues and reactions a bit weird. Wish her dialogues were better especially when she says "he is my aashiqui" (a little out of place for a Bengaluru hudugi). Or maybe I didn't follow those scenes properly. I just wanted the main plot to take over most of the times.What sets the hero apart from other story heros is that he is not too emotional or sentimental but plans for the greater good, is not consumed by everything happening. This shows so clearly when he is almost annoyed when people start looking towards him as their deliverer.Plenty of the scenes will make you just clap and whistle and go awwwe and ohhh!!Death of the mother-son scene, that guy who begs for deliverance and escape, and sacrifices himself for his wife and yet to be born baby is soo heart touching!!
That scene with the old man running around feeling his death nearing him is soo fear inducing, you can't stop yourself from feeling it so close. Also the girl baby birth scene is just so overwhelming.
Just when you think one scene is the best you have another..seems every scene competes with others to be the best..that makes the movie a winner..a complete one..period!!
The climax is one hell of a scene.. that dialogue the Mother says about leadership is what takes the movie to another level..Bestest part is the BELIEVABLE action scenes which are really great. "Aaa Obba, That One Man!! ". Most of the action movies tend to exaggerate the stunts to ridiculous squabbles, thankfully here they're terrific and so very believable.Can't wait for the second chapter..seeing they've set the benchmark so high in the very first!! Wish them all good luck for the next part!!

Caught it first day, first show. Great Watch. The movie has its moments with Yash delivering some memorables dialogs!! If you like Ugram, you are bound love this one, with Yash smashing the living daylights off the baddies..The editor did a good job stitching together the movie.
There are some misses as well..the stunts for instance...superb, but the camera work around it..with too many cuts and upclose sometimes feels a little overwhelming. Songs could have been a little modern (though the script calls for it), esp the one with Tamanna.
Nevertheless, full of adrenaline rush and eagerly awaiting Chapter 2. Btw, I am proud of the makers for putting such a good movie...definitely a blockbuster, putting Yash right at the top of Kannada Film Industry!

KGF is a Kannad movie about a south hero did heroic work like one man army against a huge numbers of bad men. Half of the movie looks like typical south action movie. Nothing new. Story is very confusing and not easy to understand well. I actually did not understand who is who especially villains. Our hero goes to Calcutta to learn strategies but there he looks like he is in Mumbai! Leave that confusion. Movie only gripping you after interval when hero goes to Kolar Gold Mines. Here story unfolding many layers of suspense and raise your curiosity. But one thing is sure that there is lack of thrill and tension which is highly required by such story plots. Second chapter is waiting for you. Perhaps it would have many twists.
However, it is watchable once. Not so super but story takes it over an average.

reviews.review_title: Yash and Prashant Neel hold the film well.
